title: Goldbach's conjectures
content:
According to Wikipedia ("Goldbach's conjecture", 20-Jul-2020, ~ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goldbach's_conjecture ) "Goldbach's conjecture ... states: Every even integer greater than 2 can be expressed as the sum of two primes." "It is also known as strong, even or binary Goldbach conjecture, to distinguish it from a weaker conjecture, known ... as the _Goldbach's weak conjecture_, the _odd Goldbach conjecture_, or the _ternary Goldbach conjecture_. This weak conjecture asserts that all odd numbers greater than 7 are the sum of three odd primes.". In the following, the terms "binary Goldbach conjecture" resp. "ternary Goldbach conjecture" will be used (following the terminology used in [Helfgott] p. 2), because there are a strong and a weak version of the ternary Goldbach conjecture. The term _Goldbach partition_ is used for a sum of two resp. three (odd) primes resulting in an even resp. odd number without further specialization.

Using the definition of a _Goldbach number_, which is "a positive even integer that can be expressed as the sum of two odd primes." (see ~ df-gbe ), "another form of the statement of Goldbach's conjecture is that all even integers greater than 4 are Goldbach numbers.". 4 is not a Goldbach number, but it is the sum of two primes (2 and 2) nevertheless. ~ sbgoldbalt shows that both forms are equivalent.

Hint (see Wikipedia, ("Goldbach's weak conjecture", 26-Jul-2020, ~ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goldbach's_weak_conjecture ): "Some state the [[weak] conjecture as 'Every odd number greater than 7 can be expressed as the sum of three odd primes.' This version excludes 7 = 2+2+3 because this requires the even prime 2. On odd numbers larger than 7 it is slightly stronger as it also excludes sums like 17 = 2+2+13, which are allowed in the other formulation. Helfgott's proof [see below] covers both versions of the conjecture. Like the other formulation, this one also immediately follows from Goldbach's strong conjecture." The definition of "weak odd Goldbach numbers", see ~ df-gbow , is the basis for "the other formulation", to formulate the weak ternary Goldbach conjecture. Alternately, ~ df-gbo provides a definition of "(strong) odd Goldbach numbers" allowing for stating the strong ternary Goldbach conjecture. In literature, the term "Goldbach number" is used for "even Goldbach numbers" (according to definition ~ df-gbe ), whereas there seems to be no explicit names and definitions for "odd Goldbach numbers". Since there are more theorems for "strong odd Goldbach numbers", "odd Goldbach numbers" refers to "strong odd Goldbach numbers" in the following. Otherwise, the term "weak odd Goldbach numbers" is explicitly used.

In contrast to the two versions of the binary Goldbach conjecture, the two versions of the ternary Goldbach conjecture are different not only for small numbers, but the strong version excludes cases like a=2+2+b in general, e.g., 23=2+2+19. Therefore, it seems to be more difficult to prove the strong ternary Goldbach conjecture than the weak version, because there are fewer possible partitions available.

Although the binary Goldbach conjecture is not proven yet, the ternary Goldbach conjecture was proven by Harald Helfgott in 2014 (the weak as well as the strong version, see Main theorem in [Helfgott] p. 2). It would be great if this proof can be formalized with Metamath (although it is not in the Metamath 100 list). This section should be a starting point for this.

The main problem will be to provide means to express the results from checking "small" numbers (performed with a computer): numbers up to about 4 x 10^18 for the binary Goldbach conjecture (see section 2 in [OeSilva] p. 2042, called "even Goldbach conjecture" here) resp. about 9 x 10^30 for the ternary Goldbach conjecture (see section 1.2.2 in [Helfgott] p. 4) or 8 x 10^26 (see theorem 2.1 in [OeSilva] p. 2057, called "odd Goldbach conjecture" here). Maybe each of the results must be provided as theorem, like ~ 6gbe , which would be quite a lot...

As proposed in the Google group discussion https://groups.google.com/g/metamath/c/DOXS4pg0h8w , this problem could be solved by using a reflective verifier or adding a concept of verification certificates that can be added into the Metamath databases as a reference. To sidestep the computation problem for now, the corresponding theorems are temporarily provided as axioms, see ~ ax-bgbltosilva , ~ ax-hgprmladder and ~ ax-tgoldbachgt .

Summary/glossary:

TermSynonymsLabel fragment Definition/TheoremRemarks
binary Goldbach partition simply "Goldbach partition" A pair of primes (p,q) that sum to an even integer 2n=p+q See ~ https://mathworld.wolfram.com/GoldbachPartition.html
weak Goldbach partition gbpart A sum of two resp. three primes resulting in an even resp. odd number without further specialization.
Goldbach partition gbpart A sum of two resp. three odd primes resulting in an even resp. odd number without further specialization.
even Goldbach number simply "Goldbach number" gbe ~ df-gbe A positive even integer that can be expressed as the sum of two odd primes. See ~ https://mathworld.wolfram.com/GoldbachNumber.html
weak odd Goldbach number gbow ~ df-gbow A positive odd integer that can be expressed as the sum of three primes.
odd Goldbach number strong odd Goldbach number gbo ~ df-gbo A positive odd integer that can be expressed as the sum of three odd primes.
strong binary Goldbach conjecture "the" Goldbach conjecture" [[*1], even Goldbach conjecture [[*2] sbgoldb Every even integer greater than 4 can be expressed as the sum of two odd primes. [[*1] Equation (1) in [ApostolNT] p. 304 or [[*2] introduction of [OeSilva] p. 2033.
binary Goldbach conjecture[[*1][[*3] strong Goldbach conjecture [[*1], even Goldbach conjecture [[*1], or simply "the Goldbach conjecture" [[*1][[*2] bgoldb, b ~ sbgoldbb Every even integer greater than 2 can be expressed as the sum of two primes. See [[*1] ~ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goldbach's_conjecture , [[*2] statement in [ApostolNT] p. 9 or [[*3] section 1.1 in [Helfgott] p. 2.
weak ternary Goldbach conjecture Goldbach's weak conjecture [[*1], odd Goldbach conjecture [[*1][[*3], ternary Goldbach conjecture [[*2], ternary Goldbach problem[[*1], three-primes problem [[*1][[*2] wtgoldb, wt ~ stgoldbwt , ~ sbgoldbwt Every odd number greater than 5 can be expressed as the sum of three primes. See [[*1] ~ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goldbach's_weak_conjecture, [[*2] section 1.1 in [Helfgott] p. 2 or [[*3] section 2.4 in [OeSilva] p. 2057.
ternary Goldbach conjecture strong ternary Goldbach conjecture, the "weak" Goldbach conjecture tgoldb, stgoldb, st ~ sbgoldbst Every odd number greater than 7 can be expressed as the sum of three odd primes. See ~ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goldbach's_weak_conjecture , ~ https://mathworld.wolfram.com/GoldbachConjecture.html or section 7.4 in [Helfgott] p. 71.
Goldbach's original conjecture (modern version) the "ternary" Goldbach conjecture mogoldb, m ~ sbgoldbm Every integer greater than 5 can be written as the sum of three primes. See ~ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goldbach's_weak_conjecture , and ~ https://mathworld.wolfram.com/GoldbachConjecture.html
Goldbach's original conjecture (original version) ogoldb, o ~ sbgoldbo Every integer greater than 2 can be written as the sum of three "primes" (considered the number 1 to be a "prime"). See ~ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goldbach's_weak_conjecture , and ~ https://mathworld.wolfram.com/GoldbachConjecture.html

df-gbe
blocks.content: Define the set of (even) Goldbach numbers, which are positive even integers that can be expressed as the sum of two odd primes. By this definition, the binary Goldbach conjecture can be expressed as ` A. n e. Even ( 4 < n -> n e. GoldbachEven ) ` . (Contributed by AV, 14-Jun-2020.)

blocks.name: df-gbow
blocks.content: Define the set of weak odd Goldbach numbers, which are positive odd integers that can be expressed as the sum of three primes. By this definition, the weak ternary Goldbach conjecture can be expressed as ` A. m e. Odd ( 5 < m -> m e. GoldbachOddW ) ` . (Contributed by AV, 14-Jun-2020.)
blocks.origin:
axiom df-gbow(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3) {
  |- wceq(cgbow, crab(s0, codd, wrex(s1, cprime, wrex(s2, cprime, wrex(s3, cprime, wceq(cv(s0), co(co(cv(s1), caddc, cv(s2)), caddc, cv(s3))))))))
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
}

blocks.name: df-gbo
blocks.content: Define the set of (strong) odd Goldbach numbers, which are positive odd integers that can be expressed as the sum of three _odd_ primes. By this definition, the strong ternary Goldbach conjecture can be expressed as ` A. m e. Odd ( 7 < m -> m e. GoldbachOdd ) ` . (Contributed by AV, 26-Jul-2020.)
blocks.origin:
axiom df-gbo(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3) {
  |- wceq(cgbo, crab(s0, codd, wrex(s1, cprime, wrex(s2, cprime, wrex(s3, cprime, wa(w3a(wcel(cv(s1), codd), wcel(cv(s2), codd), wcel(cv(s3), codd)), wceq(cv(s0), co(co(cv(s1), caddc, cv(s2)), caddc, cv(s3)))))))))
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
}

blocks.name: isgbe
blocks.content: The predicate "is an even Goldbach number". An even Goldbach number is an even integer having a Goldbach partition, i.e. which can be written as a sum of two odd primes. (Contributed by AV, 20-Jul-2020.)
blocks.origin:
thm isgbe(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0) {
  |- wb(wcel(c0, cgbe), wa(wcel(c0, ceven), wrex(s0, cprime, wrex(s1, cprime, w3a(wcel(cv(s0), codd), wcel(cv(s1), codd), wceq(c0, co(cv(s0), caddc, cv(s1))))))))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s1, c0)
} = {
  elrab2(hs0, c0, cgbe, ceven, wrex(s0, cprime, wrex(s1, cprime, w3a(wcel(cv(s0), codd), wcel(cv(s1), codd), wceq(c0, co(cv(s0), caddc, cv(s1)))))), wrex(s0, cprime, wrex(s1, cprime, w3a(wcel(cv(s0), codd), wcel(cv(s1), codd), wceq(cv(hs0), co(cv(s0), caddc, cv(s1)))))))
  2rexbidv(s0, s1, cprime, cprime, wceq(cv(hs0), c0), w3a(wcel(cv(s0), codd), wcel(cv(s1), codd), wceq(cv(hs0), co(cv(s0), caddc, cv(s1)))), w3a(wcel(cv(s0), codd), wcel(cv(s1), codd), wceq(c0, co(cv(s0), caddc, cv(s1)))))
  3anbi3d(wceq(cv(hs0), c0), wcel(cv(s0), codd), wcel(cv(s1), codd), wceq(cv(hs0), co(cv(s0), caddc, cv(s1))), wceq(c0, co(cv(s0), caddc, cv(s1))))
  eqeq1(cv(hs0), c0, co(cv(s0), caddc, cv(s1)))
  df-gbe(hs0, s0, s1)
  diff.hs0.c(c0)
  diff.hs0.c(ceven)
  diff.hs0.w(wrex(s0, cprime, wrex(s1, cprime, w3a(wcel(cv(s0), codd), wcel(cv(s1), codd), wceq(c0, co(cv(s0), caddc, cv(s1)))))))
  diff.wceq.s(s0, cv(hs0), c0)
  diff.cv.s(s0, hs0)
  diffss.ex(s0, hs0)
  diff.wceq.s(s1, cv(hs0), c0)
  diff.cv.s(s1, hs0)
  diffss.ex(s1, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s0)
  diff.hs0.s(s1)
}
blocks.pretty:
thm isgbe(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0) {
  ⊢ (c0 ∈ GoldbachEven ↔(c0 ∈ Even ∧ ∃(s0 ∈ Prime, ∃(s1 ∈ Prime,(s0 ∈ Odd ∧ s1 ∈ Odd ∧ c0 =(s0[+]s1))))))
  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
  ⊣ d(s0, c0)
  ⊣ d(s1, c0)
} = {
  elrab2(hs0, c0, cgbe, ceven, ∃(s0 ∈ Prime, ∃(s1 ∈ Prime,(s0 ∈ Odd ∧ s1 ∈ Odd ∧ c0 =(s0[+]s1)))), ∃(s0 ∈ Prime, ∃(s1 ∈ Prime,(s0 ∈ Odd ∧ s1 ∈ Odd ∧ hs0 =(s0[+]s1)))))
  2rexbidv(s0, s1, cprime, cprime, hs0 = c0, (s0 ∈ Odd ∧ s1 ∈ Odd ∧ hs0 =(s0[+]s1)), (s0 ∈ Odd ∧ s1 ∈ Odd ∧ c0 =(s0[+]s1)))
  3anbi3d(hs0 = c0, s0 ∈ Odd, s1 ∈ Odd, hs0 =(s0[+]s1), c0 =(s0[+]s1))
  eqeq1(hs0, c0, (s0[+]s1))
  df-gbe(hs0, s0, s1)
  diff.hs0.c(c0)
  diff.hs0.c(ceven)
  diff.hs0.w(∃(s0 ∈ Prime, ∃(s1 ∈ Prime,(s0 ∈ Odd ∧ s1 ∈ Odd ∧ c0 =(s0[+]s1)))))
  diff.wceq.s(s0, hs0, c0)
  diff.cv.s(s0, hs0)
  diffss.ex(s0, hs0)
  diff.wceq.s(s1, hs0, c0)
  diff.cv.s(s1, hs0)
  diffss.ex(s1, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s0)
  diff.hs0.s(s1)
}

blocks.name: isgbow
blocks.content: The predicate "is a weak odd Goldbach number". A weak odd Goldbach number is an odd integer having a Goldbach partition, i.e. which can be written as a sum of three primes. (Contributed by AV, 20-Jul-2020.)
blocks.origin:
thm isgbow(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, class c0) {
  |- wb(wcel(c0, cgbow), wa(wcel(c0, codd), wrex(s0, cprime, wrex(s1, cprime, wrex(s2, cprime, wceq(c0, co(co(cv(s0), caddc, cv(s1)), caddc, cv(s2))))))))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s1, c0)
  -| diffsc(s2, c0)
} = {
  elrab2(hs0, c0, cgbow, codd, wrex(s0, cprime, wrex(s1, cprime, wrex(s2, cprime, wceq(c0, co(co(cv(s0), caddc, cv(s1)), caddc, cv(s2)))))), wrex(s0, cprime, wrex(s1, cprime, wrex(s2, cprime, wceq(cv(hs0), co(co(cv(s0), caddc, cv(s1)), caddc, cv(s2)))))))
  2rexbidv(s0, s1, cprime, cprime, wceq(cv(hs0), c0), wrex(s2, cprime, wceq(cv(hs0), co(co(cv(s0), caddc, cv(s1)), caddc, cv(s2)))), wrex(s2, cprime, wceq(c0, co(co(cv(s0), caddc, cv(s1)), caddc, cv(s2)))))
  rexbidv(s2, cprime, wceq(cv(hs0), c0), wceq(cv(hs0), co(co(cv(s0), caddc, cv(s1)), caddc, cv(s2))), wceq(c0, co(co(cv(s0), caddc, cv(s1)), caddc, cv(s2))))
  eqeq1(cv(hs0), c0, co(co(cv(s0), caddc, cv(s1)), caddc, cv(s2)))
  df-gbow(hs0, s0, s1, s2)
  diff.hs0.c(c0)
  diff.hs0.c(codd)
  diff.hs0.w(wrex(s0, cprime, wrex(s1, cprime, wrex(s2, cprime, wceq(c0, co(co(cv(s0), caddc, cv(s1)), caddc, cv(s2)))))))
  diff.wceq.s(s0, cv(hs0), c0)
  diff.cv.s(s0, hs0)
  diffss.ex(s0, hs0)
  diff.wceq.s(s1, cv(hs0), c0)
  diff.cv.s(s1, hs0)
  diffss.ex(s1, hs0)
  diff.wceq.s(s2, cv(hs0), c0)
  diff.cv.s(s2, hs0)
  diffss.ex(s2, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s0)
  diff.hs0.s(s1)
  diff.hs0.s(s2)
}
blocks.pretty:
thm isgbow(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, class c0) {
  ⊢ (c0 ∈ GoldbachOddW ↔(c0 ∈ Odd ∧ ∃(s0 ∈ Prime, ∃(s1 ∈ Prime, ∃(s2 ∈ Prime, c0 =((s0[+]s1)[+]s2))))))
  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
  ⊣ d(s0, s2)
  ⊣ d(s1, s2)
  ⊣ d(s0, c0)
  ⊣ d(s1, c0)
  ⊣ d(s2, c0)
} = {
  elrab2(hs0, c0, cgbow, codd, ∃(s0 ∈ Prime, ∃(s1 ∈ Prime, ∃(s2 ∈ Prime, c0 =((s0[+]s1)[+]s2)))), ∃(s0 ∈ Prime, ∃(s1 ∈ Prime, ∃(s2 ∈ Prime, hs0 =((s0[+]s1)[+]s2)))))
  2rexbidv(s0, s1, cprime, cprime, hs0 = c0, ∃(s2 ∈ Prime, hs0 =((s0[+]s1)[+]s2)), ∃(s2 ∈ Prime, c0 =((s0[+]s1)[+]s2)))
  rexbidv(s2, cprime, hs0 = c0, hs0 =((s0[+]s1)[+]s2), c0 =((s0[+]s1)[+]s2))
  eqeq1(hs0, c0, ((s0[+]s1)[+]s2))
  df-gbow(hs0, s0, s1, s2)
  diff.hs0.c(c0)
  diff.hs0.c(codd)
  diff.hs0.w(∃(s0 ∈ Prime, ∃(s1 ∈ Prime, ∃(s2 ∈ Prime, c0 =((s0[+]s1)[+]s2)))))
  diff.wceq.s(s0, hs0, c0)
  diff.cv.s(s0, hs0)
  diffss.ex(s0, hs0)
  diff.wceq.s(s1, hs0, c0)
  diff.cv.s(s1, hs0)
  diffss.ex(s1, hs0)
  diff.wceq.s(s2, hs0, c0)
  diff.cv.s(s2, hs0)
  diffss.ex(s2, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s0)
  diff.hs0.s(s1)
  diff.hs0.s(s2)
}

  rexbidv(s2, cprime, wceq(cv(hs0), c0), wa(w3a(wcel(cv(s0), codd), wcel(cv(s1), codd), wcel(cv(s2), codd)), wceq(cv(hs0), co(co(cv(s0), caddc, cv(s1)), caddc, cv(s2)))), wa(w3a(wcel(cv(s0), codd), wcel(cv(s1), codd), wcel(cv(s2), codd)), wceq(c0, co(co(cv(s0), caddc, cv(s1)), caddc, cv(s2)))))

thm isgbo(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, class c0) {
  ⊢ (c0 ∈ GoldbachOdd ↔(c0 ∈ Odd ∧ ∃(s0 ∈ Prime, ∃(s1 ∈ Prime, ∃(s2 ∈ Prime,((s0 ∈ Odd ∧ s1 ∈ Odd ∧ s2 ∈ Odd)∧ c0 =((s0[+]s1)[+]s2)))))))
  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
  ⊣ d(s0, s2)
  ⊣ d(s1, s2)
  ⊣ d(s0, c0)
  ⊣ d(s1, c0)
  ⊣ d(s2, c0)
} = {

thm gbegt5(class c0) {
  ⊢ (c0 ∈ GoldbachEven → 5[<]c0)
} = {
  sylbi(c0 ∈ GoldbachEven, 5[<]c0, (c0 ∈ Even ∧ ∃(hs0 ∈ Prime, ∃(hs1 ∈ Prime,(hs0 ∈ Odd ∧ hs1 ∈ Odd ∧ c0 =(hs0[+]hs1))))))

  imp(c0 ∈ Even, ∃(hs0 ∈ Prime, ∃(hs1 ∈ Prime,(hs0 ∈ Odd ∧ hs1 ∈ Odd ∧ c0 =(hs0[+]hs1)))), 5[<]c0)
  rexlimdvv(hs0, hs1, cprime, cprime, c0 ∈ Even, (hs0 ∈ Odd ∧ hs1 ∈ Odd ∧ c0 =(hs0[+]hs1)), 5[<]c0)
  a1i(c0 ∈ Even, ((hs0 ∈ Prime ∧ hs1 ∈ Prime)→((hs0 ∈ Odd ∧ hs1 ∈ Odd ∧ c0 =(hs0[+]hs1))→ 5[<]c0)))
  ex((hs0 ∈ Prime ∧ hs1 ∈ Prime), (hs0 ∈ Odd ∧ hs1 ∈ Odd ∧ c0 =(hs0[+]hs1)), 5[<]c0)
  mpbird(((hs0 ∈ Prime ∧ hs1 ∈ Prime)∧(hs0 ∈ Odd ∧ hs1 ∈ Odd ∧ c0 =(hs0[+]hs1))), 5[<]c0, 5[<](hs0[+]hs1))
  impcom((hs0 ∈ Prime ∧ hs1 ∈ Prime), (hs0 ∈ Odd ∧ hs1 ∈ Odd ∧ c0 =(hs0[+]hs1)), 5[<](hs0[+]hs1))
  3adant3(hs0 ∈ Odd, hs1 ∈ Odd, c0 =(hs0[+]hs1), ((hs0 ∈ Prime ∧ hs1 ∈ Prime)→ 5[<](hs0[+]hs1)))
  ex((hs0 ∈ Odd ∧ hs1 ∈ Odd), (hs0 ∈ Prime ∧ hs1 ∈ Prime), 5[<](hs0[+]hs1))
  an4s(hs0 ∈ Odd, hs1 ∈ Odd, hs0 ∈ Prime, hs1 ∈ Prime, 5[<](hs0[+]hs1))
  syl2an((hs0 ∈ Odd ∧ hs0 ∈ Prime), (hs1 ∈ Odd ∧ hs1 ∈ Prime), 5[<](hs0[+]hs1), hs0 ∈(ℤ≥ ` 3), hs1 ∈(ℤ≥ ` 3))
  ancoms(hs0 ∈ Odd, hs0 ∈ Prime, hs0 ∈(ℤ≥ ` 3))
  oddprmuzge3(hs0)
  ancoms(hs1 ∈ Odd, hs1 ∈ Prime, hs1 ∈(ℤ≥ ` 3))
  oddprmuzge3(hs1)
  imp(hs0 ∈(ℤ≥ ` 3), hs1 ∈(ℤ≥ ` 3), 5[<](hs0[+]hs1))

  eluz2(hs0, nat3)
  syl5bi((3 ∈ ℤ ∧ hs0 ∈ ℤ ∧ 3[≤]hs0), hs1 ∈(ℤ≥ ` 3), 5[<](hs0[+]hs1), (3 ∈ ℤ ∧ hs1 ∈ ℤ ∧ 3[≤]hs1))
  eluz2(hs1, nat3)
  3adant1(3 ∈ ℤ, hs0 ∈ ℤ, 3[≤]hs0, ((3 ∈ ℤ ∧ hs1 ∈ ℤ ∧ 3[≤]hs1)→ 5[<](hs0[+]hs1)))
  imp(hs0 ∈ ℤ, 3[≤]hs0, ((3 ∈ ℤ ∧ hs1 ∈ ℤ ∧ 3[≤]hs1)→ 5[<](hs0[+]hs1)))
  com13(hs0 ∈ ℤ, 3[≤]hs0, (3 ∈ ℤ ∧ hs1 ∈ ℤ ∧ 3[≤]hs1), 5[<](hs0[+]hs1))
  3imp(3 ∈ ℤ, hs1 ∈ ℤ, 3[≤]hs1, (3[≤]hs0 →(hs0 ∈ ℤ → 5[<](hs0[+]hs1))))
  exp4b(3 ∈ ℤ, hs1 ∈ ℤ, 3[≤]hs1, 3[≤]hs0, (hs0 ∈ ℤ → 5[<](hs0[+]hs1)))
  com23((3 ∈ ℤ ∧ hs1 ∈ ℤ), (3[≤]hs1 ∧ 3[≤]hs0), hs0 ∈ ℤ, 5[<](hs0[+]hs1))
  adantl(3 ∈ ℤ, hs1 ∈ ℤ, (hs0 ∈ ℤ →((3[≤]hs1 ∧ 3[≤]hs0)→ 5[<](hs0[+]hs1))))
  ex(hs1 ∈ ℤ, hs0 ∈ ℤ, ((3[≤]hs1 ∧ 3[≤]hs0)→ 5[<](hs0[+]hs1)))
  syl2an(hs1 ∈ ℤ, hs0 ∈ ℤ, ((3[≤]hs1 ∧ 3[≤]hs0)→ 5[<](hs0[+]hs1)), hs1 ∈ ℝ, hs0 ∈ ℝ)

  pm3.2i(3 ∈ ℝ, 3 ∈ ℝ)
  3re()
  pm3.22(hs1 ∈ ℝ, hs0 ∈ ℝ)

  a1i((hs1 ∈ ℝ ∧ hs0 ∈ ℝ), 5 ∈ ℝ)
  5re()
  a1i((hs1 ∈ ℝ ∧ hs0 ∈ ℝ), 6 ∈ ℝ)
  6re()
  ancoms(hs1 ∈ ℝ, hs0 ∈ ℝ, (hs0[+]hs1)∈ ℝ)
  readdcl(hs0, hs1)
  ltletr(nat5, nat6, (hs0[+]hs1))
  adantl((hs0 ∈ Prime ∧ hs1 ∈ Prime), (hs0 ∈ Odd ∧ hs1 ∈ Odd ∧ c0 =(hs0[+]hs1)), (5[<]c0 ↔ 5[<](hs0[+]hs1)))
  3ad2ant3(hs0 ∈ Odd, hs1 ∈ Odd, c0 =(hs0[+]hs1), (5[<]c0 ↔ 5[<](hs0[+]hs1)))

  diff.hs1.c(c0)
  diff.hs1.c(cprime)

  diff.hs1.w(c0 ∈ Even)

  com12(wa(wcel(cv(hs0), cz), wcel(cv(hs1), cz)), w3a(wcel(nat2, cz), wcel(cv(hs2), cz), wbr(nat2, cle, cv(hs2))), wi(wbr(co(nat4, caddc, nat2), cle, co(co(cv(hs0), caddc, cv(hs1)), caddc, cv(hs2))), wbr(nat5, clt, co(co(cv(hs0), caddc, cv(hs1)), caddc, cv(hs2)))))
  3ad2ant2(wcel(nat2, cz), wcel(cv(hs2), cz), wbr(nat2, cle, cv(hs2)), wi(wa(wcel(cv(hs0), cz), wcel(cv(hs1), cz)), wi(wbr(co(nat4, caddc, nat2), cle, co(co(cv(hs0), caddc, cv(hs1)), caddc, cv(hs2))), wbr(nat5, clt, co(co(cv(hs0), caddc, cv(hs1)), caddc, cv(hs2))))))

blocks.name: gbowge7
blocks.content: Any weak odd Goldbach number is greater than or equal to 7. Because of ~ 7gbow , this bound is strict. (Contributed by AV, 20-Jul-2020.)
blocks.origin:
thm gbowge7(class c0) {
  |- wi(wcel(c0, cgbow), wbr(nat7, cle, c0))
} = {
  mpd(wcel(c0, cgbow), wbr(nat7, cle, c0), wbr(nat5, clt, c0))
  gbowgt5(c0)
  syld(wcel(c0, cgbow), wbr(nat5, clt, c0), wbr(nat7, cle, c0), wbr(co(nat5, caddc, nat1), cle, c0))
  syl(wcel(c0, cgbow), wi(wbr(nat5, clt, c0), wbr(co(nat5, caddc, nat1), cle, c0)), wcel(c0, cn))
  biimpd(wcel(c0, cn), wbr(nat5, clt, c0), wbr(co(nat5, caddc, nat1), cle, c0))
  sylancr(wcel(c0, cn), wb(wbr(nat5, clt, c0), wbr(co(nat5, caddc, nat1), cle, c0)), wcel(nat5, cz), wcel(c0, cz))
  nnzi(nat5)
  5nn()
  nnz(c0)
  zltp1le(nat5, c0)
  sylbid(wcel(c0, cgbow), wbr(co(nat5, caddc, nat1), cle, c0), wbr(nat7, cle, c0), wo(wbr(nat6, clt, c0), wceq(nat6, c0)))
  syl5bb(wcel(c0, cgbow), wbr(co(nat5, caddc, nat1), cle, c0), wo(wbr(nat6, clt, c0), wceq(nat6, c0)), wbr(nat6, cle, c0))
  breq1i(co(nat5, caddc, nat1), cle, c0, nat6)
  5p1e6()
  sylancr(wcel(c0, cgbow), wb(wbr(nat6, cle, c0), wo(wbr(nat6, clt, c0), wceq(nat6, c0))), wcel(nat6, cr), wcel(c0, cr))
  6re()
  nnred(c0, wcel(c0, cgbow))
  leloe(nat6, c0)
  jaod(wcel(c0, cgbow), wbr(nat6, clt, c0), wceq(nat6, c0), wbr(nat7, cle, c0))
  syl6ib(wcel(c0, cgbow), wbr(nat6, clt, c0), wbr(nat7, cle, c0), wbr(co(nat6, caddc, nat1), cle, c0))
  sylancr(wcel(c0, cgbow), wi(wbr(nat6, clt, c0), wbr(co(nat6, caddc, nat1), cle, c0)), wcel(nat6, cz), wcel(c0, cz))
  nnzi(nat6)
  6nn()
  nnzd(c0, wcel(c0, cgbow))
  gbowpos(c0)
  biimpd(wa(wcel(nat6, cz), wcel(c0, cz)), wbr(nat6, clt, c0), wbr(co(nat6, caddc, nat1), cle, c0))
  zltp1le(nat6, c0)
  breq1i(co(nat6, caddc, nat1), cle, c0, nat7)
  6p1e7()
  sylbi(wcel(c0, cgbow), wi(wceq(nat6, c0), wbr(nat7, cle, c0)), wa(wcel(c0, codd), wrex(hs0, cprime, wrex(hs1, cprime, wrex(hs2, cprime, wceq(c0, co(co(cv(hs0), caddc, cv(hs1)), caddc, cv(hs2))))))))
  isgbow(hs0, hs1, hs2, c0)
  adantr(wcel(c0, codd), wrex(hs0, cprime, wrex(hs1, cprime, wrex(hs2, cprime, wceq(c0, co(co(cv(hs0), caddc, cv(hs1)), caddc, cv(hs2)))))), wi(wceq(nat6, c0), wbr(nat7, cle, c0)))
  com12(wcel(c0, codd), wceq(nat6, c0), wbr(nat7, cle, c0))
  syl6bir(wceq(nat6, c0), wcel(c0, codd), wbr(nat7, cle, c0), wcel(nat6, codd))
  eleq1(nat6, c0, codd)
  mp2b(wi(wcel(nat6, codd), wbr(nat7, cle, c0)), wcel(nat6, ceven), wn(wcel(nat6, codd)))
  6even()
  evennodd(nat6)
  pm2.21(wcel(nat6, codd), wbr(nat7, cle, c0))
  diff.hs0.s(hs1)
  diff.hs0.s(hs2)
  diff.hs1.s(hs2)
  diff.hs0.c(c0)
  diff.hs1.c(c0)
  diff.hs2.c(c0)
}
blocks.pretty:
thm gbowge7(class c0) {
  ⊢ (c0 ∈ GoldbachOddW → 7[≤]c0)
} = {
  mpd(c0 ∈ GoldbachOddW, 7[≤]c0, 5[<]c0)
  gbowgt5(c0)
  syld(c0 ∈ GoldbachOddW, 5[<]c0, 7[≤]c0, (5[+]1)[≤]c0)
  syl(c0 ∈ GoldbachOddW, (5[<]c0 →(5[+]1)[≤]c0), c0 ∈ ℕ)
  biimpd(c0 ∈ ℕ, 5[<]c0, (5[+]1)[≤]c0)
  sylancr(c0 ∈ ℕ, (5[<]c0 ↔(5[+]1)[≤]c0), 5 ∈ ℤ, c0 ∈ ℤ)
  nnzi(nat5)
  5nn()
  nnz(c0)
  zltp1le(nat5, c0)
  sylbid(c0 ∈ GoldbachOddW, (5[+]1)[≤]c0, 7[≤]c0, (6[<]c0 ∨ 6 = c0))
  syl5bb(c0 ∈ GoldbachOddW, (5[+]1)[≤]c0, (6[<]c0 ∨ 6 = c0), 6[≤]c0)
  breq1i((5[+]1), cle, c0, nat6)
  5p1e6()
  sylancr(c0 ∈ GoldbachOddW, (6[≤]c0 ↔(6[<]c0 ∨ 6 = c0)), 6 ∈ ℝ, c0 ∈ ℝ)
  6re()
  nnred(c0, c0 ∈ GoldbachOddW)
  leloe(nat6, c0)
  jaod(c0 ∈ GoldbachOddW, 6[<]c0, 6 = c0, 7[≤]c0)
  syl6ib(c0 ∈ GoldbachOddW, 6[<]c0, 7[≤]c0, (6[+]1)[≤]c0)
  sylancr(c0 ∈ GoldbachOddW, (6[<]c0 →(6[+]1)[≤]c0), 6 ∈ ℤ, c0 ∈ ℤ)
  nnzi(nat6)
  6nn()
  nnzd(c0, c0 ∈ GoldbachOddW)
  gbowpos(c0)
  biimpd((6 ∈ ℤ ∧ c0 ∈ ℤ), 6[<]c0, (6[+]1)[≤]c0)
  zltp1le(nat6, c0)
  breq1i((6[+]1), cle, c0, nat7)
  6p1e7()
  sylbi(c0 ∈ GoldbachOddW, (6 = c0 → 7[≤]c0), (c0 ∈ Odd ∧ ∃(hs0 ∈ Prime, ∃(hs1 ∈ Prime, ∃(hs2 ∈ Prime, c0 =((hs0[+]hs1)[+]hs2))))))
  isgbow(hs0, hs1, hs2, c0)
  adantr(c0 ∈ Odd, ∃(hs0 ∈ Prime, ∃(hs1 ∈ Prime, ∃(hs2 ∈ Prime, c0 =((hs0[+]hs1)[+]hs2)))), (6 = c0 → 7[≤]c0))
  com12(c0 ∈ Odd, 6 = c0, 7[≤]c0)
  syl6bir(6 = c0, c0 ∈ Odd, 7[≤]c0, 6 ∈ Odd)
  eleq1(nat6, c0, codd)
  mp2b((6 ∈ Odd → 7[≤]c0), 6 ∈ Even, ¬ 6 ∈ Odd)
  6even()
  evennodd(nat6)
  pm2.21(6 ∈ Odd, 7[≤]c0)
  diff.hs0.s(hs1)
  diff.hs0.s(hs2)
  diff.hs1.s(hs2)
  diff.hs0.c(c0)
  diff.hs1.c(c0)
  diff.hs2.c(c0)
}

blocks.name: gboge9
blocks.content: Any odd Goldbach number is greater than or equal to 9. Because of ~ 9gbo , this bound is strict. (Contributed by AV, 26-Jul-2020.)
blocks.origin:
thm gboge9(class c0) {
  |- wi(wcel(c0, cgbo), wbr(nat9, cle, c0))
} = {
  sylbi(wcel(c0, cgbo), wbr(nat9, cle, c0), wa(wcel(c0, codd), wrex(hs0, cprime, wrex(hs1, cprime, wrex(hs2, cprime, wa(w3a(wcel(cv(hs0), codd), wcel(cv(hs1), codd), wcel(cv(hs2), codd)), wceq(c0, co(co(cv(hs0), caddc, cv(hs1)), caddc, cv(hs2)))))))))
  isgbo(hs0, hs1, hs2, c0)
  imp(wcel(c0, codd), wrex(hs0, cprime, wrex(hs1, cprime, wrex(hs2, cprime, wa(w3a(wcel(cv(hs0), codd), wcel(cv(hs1), codd), wcel(cv(hs2), codd)), wceq(c0, co(co(cv(hs0), caddc, cv(hs1)), caddc, cv(hs2))))))), wbr(nat9, cle, c0))
  rexlimdvv(hs0, hs1, cprime, cprime, wcel(c0, codd), wrex(hs2, cprime, wa(w3a(wcel(cv(hs0), codd), wcel(cv(hs1), codd), wcel(cv(hs2), codd)), wceq(c0, co(co(cv(hs0), caddc, cv(hs1)), caddc, cv(hs2))))), wbr(nat9, cle, c0))
  a1i(wcel(c0, codd), wi(wa(wcel(cv(hs0), cprime), wcel(cv(hs1), cprime)), wi(wrex(hs2, cprime, wa(w3a(wcel(cv(hs0), codd), wcel(cv(hs1), codd), wcel(cv(hs2), codd)), wceq(c0, co(co(cv(hs0), caddc, cv(hs1)), caddc, cv(hs2))))), wbr(nat9, cle, c0))))
  rexlimdva(hs2, cprime, wa(wcel(cv(hs0), cprime), wcel(cv(hs1), cprime)), wa(w3a(wcel(cv(hs0), codd), wcel(cv(hs1), codd), wcel(cv(hs2), codd)), wceq(c0, co(co(cv(hs0), caddc, cv(hs1)), caddc, cv(hs2)))), wbr(nat9, cle, c0))
  expimpd(wa(wa(wcel(cv(hs0), cprime), wcel(cv(hs1), cprime)), wcel(cv(hs2), cprime)), w3a(wcel(cv(hs0), codd), wcel(cv(hs1), codd), wcel(cv(hs2), codd)), wceq(c0, co(co(cv(hs0), caddc, cv(hs1)), caddc, cv(hs2))), wbr(nat9, cle, c0))
  syl5ibrcom(wa(wa(wa(wcel(cv(hs0), cprime), wcel(cv(hs1), cprime)), wcel(cv(hs2), cprime)), w3a(wcel(cv(hs0), codd), wcel(cv(hs1), codd), wcel(cv(hs2), codd))), wceq(c0, co(co(cv(hs0), caddc, cv(hs1)), caddc, cv(hs2))), wbr(nat9, cle, c0), wbr(nat9, cle, co(co(cv(hs0), caddc, cv(hs1)), caddc, cv(hs2))))

blocks.name: sbgoldbwt
blocks.content: If the strong binary Goldbach conjecture is valid, then the (weak) ternary Goldbach conjecture holds, too. (Contributed by AV, 20-Jul-2020.)

  diff.hs0.w(((7[<]s1 ∧ s1 ∈ ℤ)∧ s1 ∈ Odd))
  diff.hs1.w((((7[<]s1 ∧ s1 ∈ ℤ)∧ s1 ∈ Odd)∧ hs0 ∈ Prime))
  diff.hs2.c(cprime)
  diff.hs2.c(s1)
  diff.hs2.c(nat3)
  diff.hs2.w(s1 ∈ ℤ)
  diff.hs2.w((s1[-]3)=(hs0[+]hs1))
  diff.hs0.s(hs2)
  diff.hs1.s(hs2)
  diff.hs0.c(s1)
  diff.hs1.c(s1)
}

blocks.name: sbgoldbst
blocks.content: If the strong binary Goldbach conjecture is valid, then the (strong) ternary Goldbach conjecture holds, too. (Contributed by AV, 26-Jul-2020.)

thm sbgoldbst(setvar s0, setvar s1) {
  ⊢ (∀(s0 ∈ Even,(4[<]s0 → s0 ∈ GoldbachEven))→ ∀(s1 ∈ Odd,(7[<]s1 → s1 ∈ GoldbachOdd)))
  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
} = {
  ralrimiv(s1, codd, ∀(s0 ∈ Even,(4[<]s0 → s0 ∈ GoldbachEven)), (7[<]s1 → s1 ∈ GoldbachOdd))
  expd(∀(s0 ∈ Even,(4[<]s0 → s0 ∈ GoldbachEven)), s1 ∈ Odd, 7[<]s1, s1 ∈ GoldbachOdd)
  com12(∀(s0 ∈ Even,(4[<]s0 → s0 ∈ GoldbachEven)), (s1 ∈ Odd ∧ 7[<]s1), s1 ∈ GoldbachOdd)
  3syld((s1 ∈ Odd ∧ 7[<]s1), ∀(s0 ∈ Even,(4[<]s0 → s0 ∈ GoldbachEven)), s1 ∈ GoldbachOdd, (4[<](s1[-]3)→(s1[-]3)∈ GoldbachEven), (s1[-]3)∈ GoldbachEven)
  3syl((s1 ∈ Odd ∧ 7[<]s1), (∀(s0 ∈ Even,(4[<]s0 → s0 ∈ GoldbachEven))→(4[<](s1[-]3)→(s1[-]3)∈ GoldbachEven)), (s1 ∈ Odd ∧ 3 ∈ Odd), (s1[-]3)∈ Even)
  jctir((s1 ∈ Odd ∧ 7[<]s1), s1 ∈ Odd, 3 ∈ Odd)
  omoeALTV(s1, nat3)
  rspcv(s0, (s1[-]3), ceven, (4[<]s0 → s0 ∈ GoldbachEven), (4[<](s1[-]3)→(s1[-]3)∈ GoldbachEven))
  imbi12d(s0 =(s1[-]3), 4[<]s0, s0 ∈ GoldbachEven, 4[<](s1[-]3), (s1[-]3)∈ GoldbachEven)
  breq2(s0, (s1[-]3), nat4, clt)
  eleq1(s0, (s1[-]3), cgbe)
  syl((s1 ∈ Odd ∧ 7[<]s1), ((4[<](s1[-]3)→(s1[-]3)∈ GoldbachEven)→(s1[-]3)∈ GoldbachEven), 4[<](s1[-]3))
  imp(s1 ∈ Odd, 7[<]s1, 4[<](s1[-]3))
  syl5bir(s1 ∈ Odd, 7[<]s1, 4[<](s1[-]3), (4[+]3)[<]s1)
  breq1i((4[+]3), clt, s1, nat7)
  4p3e7()
  biimpd(s1 ∈ Odd, (4[+]3)[<]s1, 4[<](s1[-]3))
  ltaddsubd(nat4, nat3, s1, s1 ∈ Odd)
  a1i(s1 ∈ Odd, 4 ∈ ℝ)
  4re()
  a1i(s1 ∈ Odd, 3 ∈ ℝ)
  3re()
  zred(s1, s1 ∈ Odd)
  pm2.27(4[<](s1[-]3), (s1[-]3)∈ GoldbachEven)
  syl5bi((s1 ∈ Odd ∧ 7[<]s1), (s1[-]3)∈ GoldbachEven, s1 ∈ GoldbachOdd, ((s1[-]3)∈ Even ∧ ∃(hs0 ∈ Prime, ∃(hs1 ∈ Prime,(hs0 ∈ Odd ∧ hs1 ∈ Odd ∧(s1[-]3)=(hs0[+]hs1))))))
  isgbe(hs0, hs1, (s1[-]3))

  syl2anr(c1 ∈ Prime, c0 ∈ Prime, (c0[+]c1)=(c1[+]c0), c0 ∈ ℂ, c1 ∈ ℂ)
  zcnd(c0, c0 ∈ Prime)
  prmz(c0)
  zcnd(c1, c1 ∈ Prime)
  prmz(c1)
  addcom(c0, c1)
  sbgoldbaltlem1(c1, c0, c2)
  sbgoldbaltlem1(c0, c1, c2)
}

blocks.name: sbgoldbalt
blocks.content: An alternate (related to the original) formulation of the binary Goldbach conjecture: Every even integer greater than 2 can be expressed as the sum of two primes. (Contributed by AV, 22-Jul-2020.)
blocks.origin:

thm sbgoldbalt(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2) {
  ⊢ (∀(s0 ∈ Even,(4[<]s0 → s0 ∈ GoldbachEven))↔ ∀(s0 ∈ Even,(2[<]s0 → ∃(s1 ∈ Prime, ∃(s2 ∈ Prime, s0 =(s1[+]s2))))))
  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
  ⊣ d(s0, s2)
  ⊣ d(s1, s2)

blocks.name: sbgoldbb
blocks.content: If the strong binary Goldbach conjecture is valid, the binary Goldbach conjecture is valid. (Contributed by AV, 23-Dec-2021.)

blocks.name: sgoldbeven3prm
blocks.content: If the binary Goldbach conjecture is valid, then an even integer greater than 5 can be expressed as the sum of three primes: Since ` ( N - 2 ) ` is even iff ` N ` is even, there would be primes ` p ` and ` q ` with ` ( N - 2 ) = ( p + q ) ` , and therefore ` N = ( ( p + q ) + 2 ) ` . (Contributed by AV, 24-Dec-2021.)
blocks.origin:

blocks.name: sbgoldbm
blocks.content: If the strong binary Goldbach conjecture is valid, the modern version of the original formulation of the Goldbach conjecture also holds: Every integer greater than 5 can be expressed as the sum of three primes. (Contributed by AV, 24-Dec-2021.)

  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
  ⊣ d(s0, s2)
  ⊣ d(s0, s3)
  ⊣ d(s1, s2)
  ⊣ d(s1, s3)
  ⊣ d(s2, s3)

  sylbi(∀(s0 ∈ Even,(4[<]s0 → s0 ∈ GoldbachEven)), ∀(s0 ∈(ℤ≥ ` 6), ∃(s1 ∈ Prime, ∃(s2 ∈ Prime, ∃(s3 ∈ Prime, s0 =((s1[+]s2)[+]s3))))), ∀(hs0 ∈ Even,(4[<]hs0 → hs0 ∈ GoldbachEven)))

blocks.name: mogoldbb
blocks.content: If the modern version of the original formulation of the Goldbach conjecture is valid, the (weak) binary Goldbach conjecture also holds. (Contributed by AV, 26-Dec-2021.)

blocks.name: sbgoldbmb
blocks.content: The strong binary Goldbach conjecture and the modern version of the original formulation of the Goldbach conjecture are equivalent. (Contributed by AV, 26-Dec-2021.)
blocks.origin:
thm sbgoldbmb(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3) {
  |- wb(wral(s0, ceven, wi(wbr(nat4, clt, cv(s0)), wcel(cv(s0), cgbe))), wral(s0, cfv(cuz, nat6), wrex(s1, cprime, wrex(s2, cprime, wrex(s3, cprime, wceq(cv(s0), co(co(cv(s1), caddc, cv(s2)), caddc, cv(s3))))))))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
} = {
  impbii(wral(s0, ceven, wi(wbr(nat4, clt, cv(s0)), wcel(cv(s0), cgbe))), wral(s0, cfv(cuz, nat6), wrex(s1, cprime, wrex(s2, cprime, wrex(s3, cprime, wceq(cv(s0), co(co(cv(s1), caddc, cv(s2)), caddc, cv(s3))))))))
  sbgoldbm(s0, s1, s2, s3)
  sylibr(wral(s0, cfv(cuz, nat6), wrex(s1, cprime, wrex(s2, cprime, wrex(s3, cprime, wceq(cv(s0), co(co(cv(s1), caddc, cv(s2)), caddc, cv(s3))))))), wral(s0, ceven, wi(wbr(nat4, clt, cv(s0)), wcel(cv(s0), cgbe))), wral(s0, ceven, wi(wbr(nat2, clt, cv(s0)), wrex(s1, cprime, wrex(s2, cprime, wceq(cv(s0), co(cv(s1), caddc, cv(s2))))))))
  mogoldbb(s0, s1, s2, s3)
  sbgoldbalt(s0, s1, s2)
}
blocks.pretty:
thm sbgoldbmb(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3) {
  ⊢ (∀(s0 ∈ Even,(4[<]s0 → s0 ∈ GoldbachEven))↔ ∀(s0 ∈(ℤ≥ ` 6), ∃(s1 ∈ Prime, ∃(s2 ∈ Prime, ∃(s3 ∈ Prime, s0 =((s1[+]s2)[+]s3))))))
  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
  ⊣ d(s0, s2)
  ⊣ d(s0, s3)
  ⊣ d(s1, s2)
  ⊣ d(s1, s3)
  ⊣ d(s2, s3)
} = {
  impbii(∀(s0 ∈ Even,(4[<]s0 → s0 ∈ GoldbachEven)), ∀(s0 ∈(ℤ≥ ` 6), ∃(s1 ∈ Prime, ∃(s2 ∈ Prime, ∃(s3 ∈ Prime, s0 =((s1[+]s2)[+]s3))))))
  sbgoldbm(s0, s1, s2, s3)
  sylibr(∀(s0 ∈(ℤ≥ ` 6), ∃(s1 ∈ Prime, ∃(s2 ∈ Prime, ∃(s3 ∈ Prime, s0 =((s1[+]s2)[+]s3))))), ∀(s0 ∈ Even,(4[<]s0 → s0 ∈ GoldbachEven)), ∀(s0 ∈ Even,(2[<]s0 → ∃(s1 ∈ Prime, ∃(s2 ∈ Prime, s0 =(s1[+]s2))))))
  mogoldbb(s0, s1, s2, s3)
  sbgoldbalt(s0, s1, s2)
}

blocks.name: sbgoldbo
blocks.content: If the strong binary Goldbach conjecture is valid, the original formulation of the Goldbach conjecture also holds: Every integer greater than 2 can be expressed as the sum of three "primes" with regarding 1 to be a prime (as Goldbach did). Original text: "Es scheint wenigstens, dass eine jede Zahl, die groesser ist als 2, ein aggregatum trium numerorum primorum sey." (Goldbach, 1742). (Contributed by AV, 25-Dec-2021.)

blocks.name: nnsum4primesprm
blocks.content: Every prime is "the sum of at most 4" (actually one - the prime itself) primes. (Contributed by AV, 23-Jul-2020.) (Proof shortened by AV, 2-Aug-2020.)
blocks.origin:

blocks.name: nnsum4primesgbe
blocks.content: Any even Goldbach number is the sum of at most 4 (actually 2) primes. (Contributed by AV, 23-Jul-2020.) (Proof shortened by AV, 2-Aug-2020.)
blocks.origin:
thm nnsum4primesgbe(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, class c0) {
  |- wi(wcel(c0, cgbe), wrex(s0, cn, wrex(s1, co(cprime, cmap, co(nat1, cfz, cv(s0))), wa(wbr(cv(s0), cle, nat4), wceq(c0, csu(s2, co(nat1, cfz, cv(s0)), cfv(cv(s1), cv(s2))))))))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s1, c0)
  -| diffsc(s2, c0)
} = {
  syl(wcel(c0, cgbe), wrex(s0, cn, wrex(s1, co(cprime, cmap, co(nat1, cfz, cv(s0))), wa(wbr(cv(s0), cle, nat4), wceq(c0, csu(s2, co(nat1, cfz, cv(s0)), cfv(cv(s1), cv(s2))))))), wrex(s0, cn, wrex(s1, co(cprime, cmap, co(nat1, cfz, cv(s0))), wa(wbr(cv(s0), cle, nat3), wceq(c0, csu(s2, co(nat1, cfz, cv(s0)), cfv(cv(s1), cv(s2))))))))
  nnsum3primesgbe(s0, s1, s2, c0)
  reximia(s0, cn, wrex(s1, co(cprime, cmap, co(nat1, cfz, cv(s0))), wa(wbr(cv(s0), cle, nat3), wceq(c0, csu(s2, co(nat1, cfz, cv(s0)), cfv(cv(s1), cv(s2)))))), wrex(s1, co(cprime, cmap, co(nat1, cfz, cv(s0))), wa(wbr(cv(s0), cle, nat4), wceq(c0, csu(s2, co(nat1, cfz, cv(s0)), cfv(cv(s1), cv(s2)))))))
  reximdv(s1, co(cprime, cmap, co(nat1, cfz, cv(s0))), wcel(cv(s0), cn), wa(wbr(cv(s0), cle, nat3), wceq(c0, csu(s2, co(nat1, cfz, cv(s0)), cfv(cv(s1), cv(s2))))), wa(wbr(cv(s0), cle, nat4), wceq(c0, csu(s2, co(nat1, cfz, cv(s0)), cfv(cv(s1), cv(s2))))))

  mpan2i(wcel(cv(s0), cn), wbr(cv(s0), cle, nat3), wbr(cv(s0), cle, nat4), wbr(nat3, clt, nat4))
  3lt4()
  syl3anc(wcel(cv(s0), cn), wi(wa(wbr(cv(s0), cle, nat3), wbr(nat3, clt, nat4)), wbr(cv(s0), cle, nat4)), wcel(cv(s0), cr), wcel(nat3, cr), wcel(nat4, cr))
  nnre(cv(s0))
  a1i(wcel(cv(s0), cn), wcel(nat3, cr))
  3re()

blocks.name: nnsum4primesle9
blocks.content: Every integer greater than 1 and less than or equal to 8 is the sum of at most 4 primes. (Contributed by AV, 24-Jul-2020.) (Proof shortened by AV, 2-Aug-2020.)
blocks.origin:

} = {

blocks.name: nnsum4primesoddALTV
blocks.content: If the (strong) ternary Goldbach conjecture is valid, then every odd integer greater than 7 is the sum of 3 primes. (Contributed by AV, 26-Jul-2020.)
blocks.origin:
thm nnsum4primesoddALTV(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, class c0) {
  |- wi(wral(s0, codd, wi(wbr(nat7, clt, cv(s0)), wcel(cv(s0), cgbo))), wi(wa(wcel(c0, cfv(cuz, nat8)), wcel(c0, codd)), wrex(s1, co(cprime, cmap, co(nat1, cfz, nat3)), wceq(c0, csu(s2, co(nat1, cfz, nat3), cfv(cv(s1), cv(s2)))))))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s1, c0)
  -| diffsc(s2, c0)
} = {
  a1ii(wi(wral(s0, codd, wi(wbr(nat7, clt, cv(s0)), wcel(cv(s0), cgbo))), wi(wa(wcel(c0, cfv(cuz, nat8)), wcel(c0, codd)), wrex(s1, co(cprime, cmap, co(nat1, cfz, nat3)), wceq(c0, csu(s2, co(nat1, cfz, nat3), cfv(cv(s1), cv(s2))))))), diffss(s0, s1))

} = {

blocks.name: evengpop3
blocks.content: If the (weak) ternary Goldbach conjecture is valid, then every even integer greater than 8 is the sum of an odd Goldbach number and 3. (Contributed by AV, 24-Jul-2020.)
blocks.origin:

  |- wi(wral(s0, codd, wi(wbr(nat5, clt, cv(s0)), wcel(cv(s0), cgbow))), wi(wa(wcel(c0, cfv(cuz, nat9)), wcel(c0, ceven)), wrex(s1, cgbow, wceq(c0, co(cv(s1), caddc, nat3)))))
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s1, c0)
} = {
  syldc(wral(s0, codd, wi(wbr(nat5, clt, cv(s0)), wcel(cv(s0), cgbow))), wa(wcel(c0, cfv(cuz, nat9)), wcel(c0, ceven)), wrex(s1, cgbow, wceq(c0, co(cv(s1), caddc, nat3))), wi(wbr(nat5, clt, co(c0, cmin, nat3)), wcel(co(c0, cmin, nat3), cgbow)))
  rspcdv(s0, codd, co(c0, cmin, nat3), wa(wcel(c0, cfv(cuz, nat9)), wcel(c0, ceven)), wi(wbr(nat5, clt, cv(s0)), wcel(cv(s0), cgbow)), wi(wbr(nat5, clt, co(c0, cmin, nat3)), wcel(co(c0, cmin, nat3), cgbow)))

  ⊣ d(s0, c0)

} = {
  syldc(∀(s0 ∈ Odd,(5[<]s0 → s0 ∈ GoldbachOddW)), (c0 ∈(ℤ≥ ` 9)∧ c0 ∈ Even), ∃(s1 ∈ GoldbachOddW, c0 =(s1[+]3)), (5[<](c0[-]3)→(c0[-]3)∈ GoldbachOddW))

blocks.name: evengpoap3
blocks.content: If the (strong) ternary Goldbach conjecture is valid, then every even integer greater than 10 is the sum of an odd Goldbach number and 3. (Contributed by AV, 27-Jul-2020.) (Proof shortened by AV, 15-Sep-2021.)

blocks.name: nnsum4primeseven
blocks.content: If the (weak) ternary Goldbach conjecture is valid, then every even integer greater than 8 is the sum of 4 primes. (Contributed by AV, 25-Jul-2020.)

blocks.name: nnsum4primesevenALTV
blocks.content: If the (strong) ternary Goldbach conjecture is valid, then every even integer greater than 10 is the sum of 4 primes. (Contributed by AV, 27-Jul-2020.)

blocks.name: wtgoldbnnsum4prm
blocks.content: If the (weak) ternary Goldbach conjecture is valid, then every integer greater than 1 is the sum of at most 4 primes, showing that Schnirelmann's constant would be less than or equal to 4. See corollary 1.1 in [Helfgott] p. 4. (Contributed by AV, 25-Jul-2020.)

blocks.name: stgoldbnnsum4prm
blocks.content: If the (strong) ternary Goldbach conjecture is valid, then every integer greater than 1 is the sum of at most 4 primes. (Contributed by AV, 27-Jul-2020.)
blocks.origin:
thm stgoldbnnsum4prm(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4) {
  |- wi(wral(s0, codd, wi(wbr(nat7, clt, cv(s0)), wcel(cv(s0), cgbo))), wral(s1, cfv(cuz, nat2), wrex(s2, cn, wrex(s3, co(cprime, cmap, co(nat1, cfz, cv(s2))), wa(wbr(cv(s2), cle, nat4), wceq(cv(s1), csu(s4, co(nat1, cfz, cv(s2)), cfv(cv(s3), cv(s4)))))))))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s4)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s1, s4)
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
  -| diffss(s2, s4)
  -| diffss(s3, s4)
} = {
  syl(wral(s0, codd, wi(wbr(nat7, clt, cv(s0)), wcel(cv(s0), cgbo))), wral(s1, cfv(cuz, nat2), wrex(s2, cn, wrex(s3, co(cprime, cmap, co(nat1, cfz, cv(s2))), wa(wbr(cv(s2), cle, nat4), wceq(cv(s1), csu(s4, co(nat1, cfz, cv(s2)), cfv(cv(s3), cv(s4)))))))), wral(s0, codd, wi(wbr(nat5, clt, cv(s0)), wcel(cv(s0), cgbow))))
  stgoldbwt(s0)
  wtgoldbnnsum4prm(s0, s1, s2, s3, s4)
}
blocks.pretty:
thm stgoldbnnsum4prm(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4) {
  ⊢ (∀(s0 ∈ Odd,(7[<]s0 → s0 ∈ GoldbachOdd))→ ∀(s1 ∈(ℤ≥ ` 2), ∃(s2 ∈ ℕ, ∃(s3 ∈(Prime[↦](1[...]s2)),(s2[≤]4 ∧ s1 = sum(s4 ∈(1[...]s2),(s3 ` s4)))))))
  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
  ⊣ d(s0, s2)
  ⊣ d(s0, s3)
  ⊣ d(s0, s4)
  ⊣ d(s1, s2)
  ⊣ d(s1, s3)
  ⊣ d(s1, s4)
  ⊣ d(s2, s3)
  ⊣ d(s2, s4)
  ⊣ d(s3, s4)
} = {
  syl(∀(s0 ∈ Odd,(7[<]s0 → s0 ∈ GoldbachOdd)), ∀(s1 ∈(ℤ≥ ` 2), ∃(s2 ∈ ℕ, ∃(s3 ∈(Prime[↦](1[...]s2)),(s2[≤]4 ∧ s1 = sum(s4 ∈(1[...]s2),(s3 ` s4)))))), ∀(s0 ∈ Odd,(5[<]s0 → s0 ∈ GoldbachOddW)))
  stgoldbwt(s0)
  wtgoldbnnsum4prm(s0, s1, s2, s3, s4)
}

}

blocks.name: bgoldbtbndlem1
blocks.content: Lemma 1 for ~ bgoldbtbnd : the odd numbers between 7 and 13 (exclusive) are odd Goldbach numbers. (Contributed by AV, 29-Jul-2020.)

blocks.name: bgoldbtbnd
blocks.content: If the binary Goldbach conjecture is valid up to an integer ` N ` , and there is a series ("ladder") of primes with a difference of at most ` N ` up to an integer ` M ` , then the strong ternary Goldbach conjecture is valid up to ` M ` , see section 1.2.2 in [Helfgott] p. 4 with N = 4 x 10^18, taken from [OeSilva], and M = 8.875 x 10^30. (Contributed by AV, 1-Aug-2020.)
blocks.origin:
thm bgoldbtbnd(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, wff w0) {
  |- wi(w0, wral(s0, codd, wi(wa(wbr(nat7, clt, cv(s0)), wbr(cv(s0), clt, c0)), wcel(cv(s0), cgbo))))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c0, cfv(cuz, cdc(nat1, nat1))))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c1, cfv(cuz, cdc(nat1, nat1))))
  -| wi(w0, wral(s0, ceven, wi(wa(wbr(nat4, clt, cv(s0)), wbr(cv(s0), clt, c1)), wcel(cv(s0), cgbe))))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c2, cfv(cuz, nat3)))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c3, cfv(ciccp, c2)))

blocks.name: ax-bgbltosilva
blocks.content: The binary Goldbach conjecture is valid for all even numbers less than or equal to 4x10^18, see section 2 in [OeSilva] p. 2042. Temporarily provided as "axiom". (Contributed by AV, 3-Aug-2020.) (Revised by AV, 9-Sep-2021.)

blocks.name: ax-tgoldbachgt
blocks.content: Temporary duplicate of ~ tgoldbachgt , provided as "axiom" as long as this theorem is in the mathbox of Thierry Arnoux: Odd integers greater than ` ( ; 1 0 ^ ; 2 7 ) ` have at least a representation as a sum of three odd primes. Final statement in section 7.4 of [Helfgott] p. 70 , expressed using the set ` G ` of odd numbers which can be written as a sum of three odd primes. (Contributed by Thierry Arnoux, 22-Dec-2021.)
blocks.origin:
axiom ax-tgoldbachgt(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4, setvar s5, class c0, class c1) {
  |- wrex(s0, cn, wa(wbr(cv(s0), cle, co(cdc(nat1, nat0), cexp, cdc(nat2, nat7))), wral(s1, c0, wi(wbr(cv(s0), clt, cv(s1)), wcel(cv(s1), c1)))))
  -| wceq(c0, crab(s2, cz, wn(wbr(nat2, cdvds, cv(s2)))))
  -| wceq(c1, crab(s2, c0, wrex(s3, cprime, wrex(s4, cprime, wrex(s5, cprime, wa(w3a(wcel(cv(s3), c0), wcel(cv(s4), c0), wcel(cv(s5), c0)), wceq(cv(s2), co(co(cv(s3), caddc, cv(s4)), caddc, cv(s5)))))))))
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s4)
  -| diffss(s0, s5)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s3, s4)
  -| diffss(s3, s5)
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
  -| diffss(s4, s5)
  -| diffss(s2, s4)
  -| diffss(s2, s5)
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s1, s4)
  -| diffss(s1, s5)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffsc(s0, c1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s3, c0)
  -| diffsc(s4, c0)
  -| diffsc(s5, c0)
  -| diffsc(s2, c0)
}

axiom ax-tgoldbachgt(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4, setvar s5, class c0, class c1) {
  ⊢ ∃(s0 ∈ ℕ,(s0[≤](cdc(1, 0)[^]cdc(2, 7))∧ ∀(s1 ∈ c0,(s0[<]s1 → s1 ∈ c1))))
  ⊣ c0 = { s2 ∈ ℤ | ¬ 2[||]s2 }
  ⊣ c1 = { s2 ∈ c0 | ∃(s3 ∈ Prime, ∃(s4 ∈ Prime, ∃(s5 ∈ Prime,((s3 ∈ c0 ∧ s4 ∈ c0 ∧ s5 ∈ c0)∧ s2 =((s3[+]s4)[+]s5)))))}
  ⊣ d(s0, s3)
  ⊣ d(s0, s4)
  ⊣ d(s0, s5)
  ⊣ d(s0, s2)
  ⊣ d(s3, s4)
  ⊣ d(s3, s5)
  ⊣ d(s2, s3)
  ⊣ d(s4, s5)
  ⊣ d(s2, s4)
  ⊣ d(s2, s5)
  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
  ⊣ d(s1, s3)
  ⊣ d(s1, s4)
  ⊣ d(s1, s5)
  ⊣ d(s1, s2)
  ⊣ d(s0, c1)
  ⊣ d(s0, c0)
  ⊣ d(s3, c0)
  ⊣ d(s4, c0)
  ⊣ d(s5, c0)
  ⊣ d(s2, c0)
}

blocks.name: tgoldbachgtALTV
blocks.content: Variant of Thierry Arnoux's ~ tgoldbachgt using the symbols ` Odd ` and ` GoldbachOdd ` : The ternary Goldbach conjecture is valid for large odd numbers (i.e. for all odd numbers greater than a fixed ` m ` ). This is proven by Helfgott (see section 7.4 in [Helfgott] p. 70) for ` m ` = 10^27. (Contributed by AV, 2-Aug-2020.) (Revised by AV, 15-Jan-2022.)
blocks.origin:
thm tgoldbachgtALTV(setvar s0, setvar s1) {
  |- wrex(s0, cn, wa(wbr(cv(s0), cle, co(cdc(nat1, nat0), cexp, cdc(nat2, nat7))), wral(s1, codd, wi(wbr(cv(s0), clt, cv(s1)), wcel(cv(s1), cgbo)))))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
} = {
  ax-tgoldbachgt(s0, s1, hs0, hs3, hs2, hs1, codd, cgbo)
  dfodd3(hs0)
  df-gbo(hs0, hs3, hs2, hs1)
  diffss.ex(s0, hs3)
  diff.hs3.s(s0)
  diffss.ex(s0, hs2)
  diff.hs2.s(s0)
  diffss.ex(s0, hs1)
  diff.hs1.s(s0)
  diffss.ex(s0, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s0)
  diff.hs3.s(hs2)
  diff.hs3.s(hs1)
  diff.hs0.s(hs3)
  diff.hs2.s(hs1)
  diff.hs0.s(hs2)
  diff.hs0.s(hs1)
  diffss.ex(s1, hs3)
  diff.hs3.s(s1)
  diffss.ex(s1, hs2)
  diff.hs2.s(s1)
  diffss.ex(s1, hs1)
  diff.hs1.s(s1)
  diffss.ex(s1, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s1)
  diff.cgbo.s(s0)
  diff.codd.s(s0)
  diff.hs3.c(codd)
  diff.hs2.c(codd)
  diff.hs1.c(codd)
  diff.hs0.c(codd)
}

blocks.name: bgoldbachlt
blocks.content: The binary Goldbach conjecture is valid for small even numbers (i.e. for all even numbers less than or equal to a fixed big ` m ` ). This is verified for m = 4 x 10^18 by Oliveira e Silva, see ~ ax-bgbltosilva . (Contributed by AV, 3-Aug-2020.) (Revised by AV, 9-Sep-2021.)

blocks.name: ax-hgprmladder
blocks.content: There is a partition ("ladder") of primes from 7 to 8.8 x 10^30 with parts ("rungs") having lengths of at least 4 and at most N - 4, see section 1.2.2 in [Helfgott] p. 4. Temporarily provided as "axiom". (Contributed by AV, 3-Aug-2020.) (Revised by AV, 9-Sep-2021.)

blocks.name: tgblthelfgott
blocks.content: The ternary Goldbach conjecture is valid for all odd numbers less than 8.8 x 10^30 (actually 8.875694 x 10^30, see section 1.2.2 in [Helfgott] p. 4, using ~ bgoldbachlt , ~ ax-hgprmladder and ~ bgoldbtbnd . (Contributed by AV, 4-Aug-2020.) (Revised by AV, 9-Sep-2021.)

blocks.name: tgoldbachlt
blocks.content: The ternary Goldbach conjecture is valid for small odd numbers (i.e. for all odd numbers less than a fixed big ` m ` greater than 8 x 10^30). This is verified for m = 8.875694 x 10^30 by Helfgott, see ~ tgblthelfgott . (Contributed by AV, 4-Aug-2020.) (Revised by AV, 9-Sep-2021.)
blocks.origin:

blocks.name: tgoldbach
blocks.content: The ternary Goldbach conjecture is valid. Main theorem in [Helfgott] p. 2. This follows from ~ tgoldbachlt and ~ ax-tgoldbachgt . (Contributed by AV, 2-Aug-2020.) (Revised by AV, 9-Sep-2021.)
blocks.origin:
